ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lectures with some prerecorded material
In person lecture plus pre-class videos
Both recorded lectures and live virtual lectures with breakout rooms.
None
Recorded lectures along with live bi weekly zoom lectures
Recorded supplemental material
There were many helpful recorded lectures available.
There were also recorded lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Review of a lot of calculus concepts that helped me build my foundation for future engineering classes to come
Multivariable Calculus
Familiarity with the concepts and applications of multivariable calculus.
The class covered topics in multi-variable calculus.
generalizations of single variable calculus concepts

I learned about Calculus 3 concepts such as double and triple integration, finding the minimum and maximum through optimization methods, and analyzing multivariable surfaces with their curl and divergence.
Calculus 3
3D calculations, multivariable integration, and other skills.
Obviously, multivariable calculus, but also how to work through multistep problems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strength was that everything was well structured and clear with a nice format of prerecorded videos, live lectures, quizzes, and homework.

Having the pre-class videos was really helpful since sometimes it can be hard to fully comprehend concepts that just get brushed over in lecture. Having the coaching sessions also helped when I was not doing well.

The focus of the course is interesting for anyone who has some affinity for mathematics. However, for someone who has never taken multivariable calculus it can be overwhelming at times, especially if your other courses do not allow you the time to visit office hours or peer tutoring sessions.

Strengths: the pre-recorded videos were really helpful; the content is arranged in a very well-organized manner; the problem sets help to reinforce concepts and practice them.
Weaknesses: with textbook readings, recorded lectures, and live virtual class, it sometimes might feel a bit redundant.
The psets were very useful for understanding the material.

I feel like this course is too difficult. Most people who take this course are freshmen, and this really isn't the course to take if you want to transition to the college lifestyle with ease. It was just simply too difficult. The content in class was super fast paced, and while I understood it most of the time, sometimes it's just so hard because the teacher just has to move on. It's too fast, and too difficult.

A lot of this class involves self learning through watching external videos and reading. This could either be a disadvantage or boon depending on one's perspective. I was grateful to be able to work with other students and collaborate with each other, something my other classes sometimes prohibit.
The recorded lectures were wonderful. There were no problems that I had with the course.

The ability to learn was greatly hindered by the virtual mode of learning. It's hard to think of a means to improve this, but it would help if the lectures were more steered towards elaborating on the videos rather them repeating them. It is good that there were a lot of office hours.
I thought the order of exposure to topics was very logical. The only weakness I believe was connecting the mathematical ideas more to real-world phenomena to improve understanding.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not much could have been improved, very well geared towards online learning
The modules were a great format.

The 3 mid-term format where your mid-terms are weighted depending on how well you have done is a helpful feature built into the course. It helps to reduce the stresses of the class in the virtual format.
Recorded lectures really helped in my opinion, but sometimes it made the live lectures feel a bit repetitive.
The class nominally followed the flipped classroom model. In fact, class time was redundant.

I feel like this course didn't do well to adapt with COVID. Firstly, our final grades didn't end up getting curved at all because most people did "better" on exams. I feel like this is wrong - we are living in a tough time and I already heard this course was super difficult, and it really did not show any leniency. Professors did not really advertise office hours and I feel like they have to understand how difficult it is to learn this course online.

Professor Hall's videos were very helpful with understanding various concepts in class. The undergraduate learning assistants were great help with walking through various problems involving many topics.

Again, the lecture videos that were available online were extremely helpful and it was great that we could go back and review the recordings as many times as we liked. The in-class activities over zoom also worked surprisingly well and were helpful too.
The virtual set up complicated the already hard course. Despite this, it seems they did the best they could.
I think modes of help and collaboration could have been made more accessible.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Very well prepared course and very useful material for a lot of STEM majors

Yes! People always give it a harsh review, but I actually really enjoyed Math 120. The pace and format was great and I feel like I actually understand the concepts and the theorems behind them. I would take this over 151.
Yes, however, be prepared for a rigorous workload.
Yes, it is a nice continuation of previous calculus classes without becoming too overwhelming.

Math 120 is exactly what it purports to be. Nothing more; nothing less. And for me that was alright! Concepts were generally very easy to follow but in some places lacking rigor (We never covered higher dimensional definitions of limits). The weekly psets weren't too bad, and it was fun to have a lot of friends taking the class. Your experience (and enjoyment of) this class will depend a lot on your instructor.

I would not recommend this course to another student, especially as a freshman unless you are fine with spending hours upon hours on Math 120. I spent many days just doing math all day, and I felt like it was hard to focus on any other classes. I truly loved math in the past, but this course was just too difficult and too fast. The exams were nothing like the problem sets - especially the second one. It was the first time I severely failed a midterm, and it basically ruined my grade. We are not exposed to enough practice. Honestly, I feel like the course should be easier and there should be two problem sets a week. Even after completing the problem sets, I still feel I don't fully grasp the concepts.

I am neutral on recommending this course because it is truly dependent on how the student is like. Personally, I would have preferred a more involved approach to learning but someone else who thrives in a self-studying environment could enjoy this class.
Yes. Even as a  general prerequisite class, it was pretty enjoyable and well organized.
I would not recommend this course unless someone was interested in Physics or Math. It was very steered towards math minded people.
It is a logical class to take in the progression of mathematics. However, I cannot compare it to similar courses such as ENAS 151.
